src:
Minst 24 nye straffesaker knyttes til Nav-skandalen
Norske tingretter har funnet over 20 nye saker hvor uskyldige kan ha blitt d√∏mt for trygdesvindel. Dette kommer i tillegg til de 48 allerede kjente sakene.
01 Nov 2019, 14:47 by NTB-Marius Helge Larsen



Norske tingretter jobber med √• f√• oversikt over sakene i Nav-komplekset. üì∑ Foto: Gorm Kallestad / NTB scanpix. Galleri



Norske tingretter jobber med √• f√• oversikt over sakene i Nav-komplekset. üì∑ Foto: Berit Roald / NTB scanpix. Galleri


Domstolene g√•r n√• gjennom alle tidligere dommer for √• se om flere kan v√¶re uriktig d√∏mt for √• ha tatt med trygdeytelser til andre E√òS-land.
S√• langt er det funnet minst 24 nye saker som mistenkes √• v√¶re basert p√• feil tolkning av loven, men det understrekes at flere av sakene m√• vurderes n√¶rmere f√∏r man kan konkludere sikkert.
I f√∏rste omgang er det sl√•tt fast at loven er blitt feiltolket i saker etter 2012 hvor Nav-brukere har tatt med seg sykepenger, arbeidsavklaringspenger og/eller pleiepenger til andre E√òS-land. Det er disse sakene domstolene n√• jobber med √• f√• oversikt over.
Ubetinget fengsel
NTB har f√•tt forel√∏pige tall fra rundt halvparten av landets 60 tingretter. Mange opplyser at de ikke har funnet noen slike saker, mens andre har avdekket noen nye saker.
I flere av de nye sakene er de tiltalte blitt d√∏mt til ubetingede fengselsstraffer i opptil flere m√•neder.
* Oslo tingrett har funnet √•tte nye saker, i tillegg til ni saker som ble kjent mandag
* Nedre Telemark tingrett har funnet tre nye saker, i tillegg til to saker som ble kjent mandag
* Fredrikstad og Halden tingretter har funnet sju nye saker, i tillegg til to saker som ble kjent mandag
* Follo tingrett har funnet minst to nye saker
* Fosen tingrett, Heggen og Fr√∏land tingrett og Alta og Hammerfest tingrett har funnet √©n ny sak hver, alts√• tre til sammen.
* Stavanger tingrett har trolig funnet √©n sak
Usikkerhet
I noen av de nye sakene har den d√∏mte delvis oppholdt seg i andre E√òS-land, men ogs√• delvis i utlandet for √∏vrig.
Dermed er det ikke sikkert at hele grunnlaget for straffen er uriktig, men alts√• deler av det, slik at den d√∏mte skulle hatt lavere straff og lavere krav om tilbakebetaling.
Denne uken oppdaget politiet i Agder en slik sak, noe som f√∏rte til at en 38 √•r gammel mann ble l√∏slatt fra fengsel torsdag.
Mannen ble i januar d√∏mt til 30 dagers fengsel for √• ha svindlet til seg 113.075 kroner i arbeidsavklaringspenger. Han startet soningen 17. oktober, skriver F√¶drelandsvennen.
‚Äì Han ble l√∏slatt i g√•r etter beslutning herfra, s√•kalt soningsavbrudd. Han hadde da sonet 14 dager av dommen, sier p√•taleleder Terje K. Skaar i Agder-politiet.
Saken kommer i tillegg til de uriktige Nav-dommene Riksadvokaten varslet om mandag.
‚Äì Stor jobb
Domstolsadministrasjonen jobber med √• f√• oversikt over omfanget av hele trygdesaken.
‚Äì Vi f√•r fortl√∏pende meldinger om saker tingrettene har funnet, men de m√• gjennomg√•s n√∏ye. Vi har blant annet f√•tt meldinger om saker som ikke h√∏rer hjemme i dette komplekset, blant annet hvor trygdeytelser er tatt med til land utenfor E√òS, sier kommunikasjonssjef Yngve Brox i Domstolsadministrasjonen til NTB.
En jurist jobber n√• for fullt med √• gjennomg√• sakene som er kommet inn. Samtidig er det enn√• noen av de store tingrettene som ikke har meldt inn sine saker.
‚Äì Det er en forferdelig stor jobb. Norske domstoler har mange saker med trygdesvindel hvert √•r. Vi har n√• bedt domstolene om √• v√¶re ferdige innen onsdag i neste uke, og s√• regner vi med √• ha en oversikt klar torsdag eller fredag, sier Brox.
Parallelt med gjennomgangen av saker fra etter 2012 som handler om sykepenger, arbeidsavklaringspenger og/eller pleiepenger, har Riksadvokaten bedt om √• f√• avklart om feiltolkningen av loven ogs√• gjelder flere trygdeytelser og lenger tilbake i tid. Dermed kan skandalen komme til √• vokse enda mer i omfang.

Dagpenger kan v√¶re en del av Nav-skandalen: Kvinne d√∏mt i Stavanger


Professor: Nav-svindel straffes hardere enn hvitsnippforbrytelser
text:
At least 24 new criminal cases are linked to the Nav scandal
Norwegian district courts have found over 20 new cases where innocents may have been convicted of social security fraud. This is in addition to the 48 cases already known.
01 Nov 2019, 14:47 by NTB-Marius Helge Larsen



Norwegian District Courts are working to get an overview of the cases in the Nav complex. üì∑ Photo: Gorm Kallestad / NTB scanpix. Gallery



Norwegian District Courts are working to get an overview of the cases in the Nav complex. üì∑ Photo: Berit Roald / NTB scanpix. Gallery


The courts are now reviewing all previous judgments to see if more people may be wrongly convicted of bringing social security benefits to other EEA countries.
So far, at least 24 new cases have been found that are suspected to be based on the misinterpretation of the law, but it is emphasized that several of the cases need to be considered more closely before it can be concluded conclusively.
Initially, it has been established that the law has been misinterpreted in cases after 2012 where Nav users have taken sickness benefit, work clarification money and / or care money to other EEA countries. These are the cases the courts are currently working on to get an overview of.
Unconditional jail
NTB has received preliminary figures from about half of the country's 60 district courts. Many report that they have not found any such cases, while others have uncovered some new cases.
In several of the new cases, the defendants have been sentenced to unconditional prison sentences for up to several months.
* Oslo District Court has found eight new cases, in addition to nine cases that became known on Monday
* Lower Telemark District Court has found three new cases, in addition to two cases that became known on Monday
* Fredrikstad and Halden district courts have found seven new cases, in addition to two cases that became known on Monday
* Follo District Court has found at least two new cases
* Fosen district court, Heggen and Fr√∏land district court and Alta and Hammerfest district court have found one new case each, ie three in total.
* Stavanger District Court has probably found one case
Insecurity
In some of the new cases, the convicted person has resided partly in other EEA countries, but also partly abroad.
Thus, the entire basis of the punishment may not be wrong, but thus parts of it, so that the convicted person would have lower penalties and lower reimbursement requirements.
This week, police in Agder discovered one such case, which resulted in a 38-year-old man being released from jail Thursday.
In January, the man was sentenced to 30 days in prison for fraudulently earning NOK 113,075 in work-clearing money. He started the sentence on October 17, writes the Fatherland friend.
- He was released yesterday following a decision from here, called a termination of atonement. He had then served 14 days of the sentence, says prosecutor Terje K. Skaar of the Agder police.
The case comes in addition to the incorrect Nav verdicts the Attorney General announced on Monday.
- Great job
The judicial administration is working to get an overview of the scope of the entire social security case.
- We receive continuous reports on cases the district courts have found, but they must be carefully reviewed. Among other things, we have received reports of cases that do not belong in this complex, including where social security benefits have been taken to countries outside the EEA, says Communications Manager Yngve Brox in the Court Administration to NTB.
A lawyer is now working fully to review the cases that have been filed. At the same time, some of the large district courts have not yet filed their cases.
- It's a terrible job. Norwegian courts have many cases of social security fraud every year. We have now asked the courts to finish by Wednesday of next week, and then we expect to have an overview ready Thursday or Friday, says Brox.
In parallel with the review of cases from post-2012 concerning sickness benefit, work-clarification money and / or nursing money, the Attorney General has asked to clarify whether the misinterpretation of the law also applies to more social security benefits and further back in time. Thus, the scandal may grow even more in scope.

Allowance may be part of the Nav scandal: Woman convicted in Stavanger


Professor: Nav fraud is punished harder than white-collar crimes
